content: Residential energy efficiency can benefit consumers by reducing utility bills and supporting national environmental policy objectives. Various policies, including tax incentives, have been adopted since the 1970s to increase conservation and energy efficiency. The federal government faces uncertainty in determining the best policy tools to meet energy-efficiency objectives. In 2016, one-fifth of total energy consumed in the United States was consumed by residential sectors. The federal government is uncertain about which policy tools to use for energy efficiency. In 2016, one-fifth of the energy consumed in the US was by residential sectors. Residential energy consumption has slightly decreased in recent years. Residential energy consumption has fallen slightly in recent years, with per capita energy use trending downward since the mid- to late-2000s. Efficiency gains have helped keep aggregate residential energy use relatively flat or even slightly declining despite the use of more energy-demanding technologies. Despite efficiency gains, experts believe there is still potential for increased energy efficiency in the residential sector. Concerns persist that consumers may not invest optimally in energy efficiency, leading to debates about the level of investment needed. Increasing energy efficiency could potentially reduce residential energy use per capita. Increasing energy efficiency in the residential sector may not be optimal due to consumer investment concerns. Tax credits are explored as a policy option to promote residential energy efficiency. Tax credits are explored as a policy option for promoting residential energy efficiency by addressing market failures and barriers. An economic rationale is provided for these incentives to correct suboptimal investment in energy-efficient technologies. For the 2017 tax year, taxpayers can claim tax credits for residential energy-efficiency and renewable-energy technologies. The nonbusiness energy property tax credit allows for credits on improvements to the building envelope. The nonbusiness energy property tax credit (IRC §25C) allows taxpayers to claim a tax credit for energy-efficiency improvements to their primary residence's building envelope and high-efficiency heating, cooling, and water-heating appliances. The credit is calculated as 10% of expenditures on improvements plus the cost of energy-efficient property capped at a specific amount. The Section 25C tax credit allows taxpayers to claim a credit for energy-efficient improvements to their primary residence. The credit is calculated as 10% of expenditures on building envelope improvements and high-efficiency appliances, capped at $500. Taxpayers generally claim the maximum amount for energy-efficient property. The $500 cap applies to claims made in the current year and the prior tax year. The Section 25C tax credit is capped at $500 for claims made in the current and prior tax year. The credit expired at the end of 2017. Another credit, the residential energy efficient property tax credit (IRC §25D), allows taxpayers to claim a tax credit for renewable energy properties installed on their residence. The residential energy efficient property tax credit (IRC §25D) allows taxpayers to claim a tax credit for renewable energy properties installed on their residence. The credit rate is 30% for 2017, decreasing to 26% in 2020 and 22% in 2021, with the credit expiring after 2021. The maximum value of the credit for renewable-energy-generating technologies is not capped. The Section 25D tax credit rate is set to decrease from 30% in 2017 to 26% in 2020 and 22% in 2021, expiring after 2021. The maximum value of the credit for renewable-energy-generating technologies is uncapped. For more details, refer to Appendices A and B for eligibility specifications and legislative history.
